title: House Intelligence Chairman Schiff Accuses Intelligence Chief of Withholding ‘Urgent’ Whistleblower Complaint
text:
WASHINGTON—House Intelligence Committee Chairman Adam Schiff issued a subpoena to the nation’s top intelligence official Friday night, seeking to force him to turn over a whistleblower complaint that the intelligence community’s inspector general has allegedly deemed a matter of “urgent concern.”

The identity of the whistleblower and the nature of the complaint weren’t revealed. But in a news release Friday night, Mr. Schiff (D., Calif.) said the inspector general had determined the complaint to be credible and notified his House committee of the matter on Monday.

Mr. Schiff said he asked acting Director of National Intelligence Joseph Maguire to turn over the full, unredacted complaint the next day, and he suggested it was being withheld to protect President Trump or other administration officials.

Mr. Schiff said he also sought all records pertaining to the Office of the Director of National Intelligence’s involvement in the matter and any correspondence with others in the executive branch, including the White House.

The White House didn’t immediately respond to a request for comment.

But earlier on Friday, the Office of the Director of National Intelligence rebuffed Mr. Schiff’s request and stated that it would withhold the whistleblower complaint in part because it involves confidential and “potentially privileged communications by persons outside the Intelligence Community,” according to the House committee’s news release.

A senior intelligence official said in a statement Friday night that the subpoena was being reviewed and would be responded to appropriately.

The Office of the Director of National Intelligence and Mr. Maguire “are committed to fully complying with the law and upholding whistleblower protections and have done so here,” the statement said.

In a letter accompanying the subpoena to Mr. Maguire, Mr. Schiff said the acting director of national intelligence was failing to comply with his legal obligations to turn over the complaint.

“You do not possess the authority to withhold from the Committee a whistleblower disclosure from within the Intelligence Community that is intended for Congress,” Mr. Schiff wrote in the letter. “The committee can only conclude, based on this remarkable confluence of factors, that the serious misconduct at issue involves the President of the United States and/or other senior White House or Administration officials.”

Mr. Maguire took over as the Trump administration’s top intelligence official after Dan Coats and his top deputy, Sue Gordon, resigned last month amid pressure from the White House.
